fr:title.text: Strong morphisms of adjunctions and the Beck–Chevalley condition

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Strong morphisms of adjunctions and the Beck–Chevalley condition

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The condition that a lax morphism of adjunctions be right strong is sometimes referred to as the Beck–Chevalley condition, e.g. by Uemura. Indeed, the right-hand mates in a lax morphism of adjunctions are occasionally referred to as Beck–Chevalley transformations.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Abstract and Concrete Type Theories
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: @phdthesis{uemura-2021-thesis, author = {Uemura, Taichi}, address = {Amsterdam}, publisher = {Institute for Logic, Language and Computation}, school = {Universiteit van Amsterdam}, url = {https://www.illc.uva.nl/cms/Research/Publications/Dissertations/DS-2021-09.text.pdf}, year = {2021}, title = {Abstract and Concrete Type Theories}, }

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal {K} be a bicategory, and let A \equiv {\mathopen {}\left (l_A\dashv r_A\colon A_1\to A_0\right )\mathclose {}} and B \equiv {\mathopen {}\left (l_B\dashv r_B\colon B_1\to B_0\right )\mathclose {}} be a pair of adjunctions in \mathcal {K}. Fix a pair of morphisms {A_0}\xrightarrow {{f_0}}{B_0} and {A_1}\xrightarrow {{f_1}}{B_1}.

Let \mathcal {K} be a bicategory, and let A \equiv {\mathopen {}\left (l_A\dashv r_A\colon A_1\to A_0\right )\mathclose {}} and B \equiv {\mathopen {}\left (l_B\dashv r_B\colon B_1\to B_0\right )\mathclose {}} be a pair of adjunctions in \mathcal {K}. Then a (left and right) lax morphism {A}\xrightarrow {{f}}{B} between the two adjunctions is given by a pair of maps {A_0}\xrightarrow {{f_0}}{B_0} and {A_1}\xrightarrow {{f_1}}{B_1} together with a pair of mates {l_B\circ f_0}\xrightarrow {{l_f}}{f_1\circ l_A} and {f_0\circ r_A}\xrightarrow {{r_f}}{r_B\circ f_1} as depicted below:

html:ol.html:li: When the left mate is invertible, we say that {A}\xrightarrow {{f}}{B} is (left strong) and right lax.
When the right mate is invertible, we say that {A}\xrightarrow {{f}}{B} is (right strong) and left lax.
When both mates are invertible, we say that {A}\xrightarrow {{f}}{B} is strong.

fr:title.text: Strong morphisms of adjunctions and the Beck–Chevalley condition

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Strong morphisms of adjunctions and the Beck–Chevalley condition

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The condition that a lax morphism of adjunctions be right strong is sometimes referred to as the Beck–Chevalley condition, e.g. by Uemura. Indeed, the right-hand mates in a lax morphism of adjunctions are occasionally referred to as Beck–Chevalley transformations.

Let \mathcal {K} be a bicategory, and let A \equiv {\mathopen {}\left (l_A\dashv r_A\colon A_1\to A_0\right )\mathclose {}} and B \equiv {\mathopen {}\left (l_B\dashv r_B\colon B_1\to B_0\right )\mathclose {}} be a pair of adjunctions in \mathcal {K}. Fix a pair of morphisms {A_0}\xrightarrow {{f_0}}{B_0} and {A_1}\xrightarrow {{f_1}}{B_1}.

Let \mathcal {K} be a bicategory, and let A \equiv {\mathopen {}\left (l_A\dashv r_A\colon A_1\to A_0\right )\mathclose {}} and B \equiv {\mathopen {}\left (l_B\dashv r_B\colon B_1\to B_0\right )\mathclose {}} be a pair of adjunctions in \mathcal {K}. Then a (left and right) lax morphism {A}\xrightarrow {{f}}{B} between the two adjunctions is given by a pair of maps {A_0}\xrightarrow {{f_0}}{B_0} and {A_1}\xrightarrow {{f_1}}{B_1} together with a pair of mates {l_B\circ f_0}\xrightarrow {{l_f}}{f_1\circ l_A} and {f_0\circ r_A}\xrightarrow {{r_f}}{r_B\circ f_1} as depicted below:

html:ol.html:li: When the left mate is invertible, we say that {A}\xrightarrow {{f}}{B} is (left strong) and right lax.
When the right mate is invertible, we say that {A}\xrightarrow {{f}}{B} is (right strong) and left lax.
When both mates are invertible, we say that {A}\xrightarrow {{f}}{B} is strong.
